description: From Middle English ternysshen, a borrowing from Old French terniss-, stem of ternir (“to make dim, make wan”), borrowed from Frankish *darnijan (“to conceal”). Doublet of dern and darn.

entries.meaning: Oxidation or discoloration, especially of a decorative metal exposed to air.
examples: Precipitated calcium carbonate, a very fine powdery form, is used as a basis for many tooth powders and pastes. As whiting it finds a wide use in cleaning metals of their tarnishes.

verbs.description: tarnish (third-person singular simple present tarnishes, present participle tarnishing, simple past and past participle tarnished)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To oxidize or discolor due to oxidation.
examples: Careful storage of silver will prevent it from tarnishing.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To compromise, damage, soil, or sully.
examples: He is afraid that she will tarnish his reputation if he disagrees with her.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, figurative) To lose its lustre or attraction; to become dull.
